docs.title: Test PyPI Pru
docs.text: Welcome to the documentation for test_pypi_pru, a Python project compiled with Cython demonstrating professional packaging with scikit-build-core.

docs.title: 🚀 Features
docs.text:
• ✅ Compiled with Cython for maximum performance
  • ✅ Native binaries - no .py files in distribution
  • ✅ Complete type hints with .pyi stub files
  • ✅ Optimized numerical functions with NumPy
  • ✅ DataFrame utilities with Pandas

docs.title: 📦 Installation
docs.text:
Install the package from Test PyPI:

pip install -i https://test.pypi.org/simple/ test-pypi-pru

For the stable version from PyPI (when available):

pip install test-pypi-pru

docs.title: Requirements
docs.text:
• Python >= 3.11
  • NumPy >= 2.4.2
  • Pandas >= 3.0.0

docs.title: 🎯 Quick Start
docs.text:
from test_pypi_pru import func1, func2, get_dataframe, my_function
import numpy as np

# Numerical operations
data = np.array([1, 2, 3, 4, 5])
squared = func1(data)
print(squared)  # [1 4 9 16 25]

# Working with DataFrames
df = get_dataframe()
print(df)

# Main function
result = my_function(5, 3)
print(result)  # 15

docs.title: 📚 Package Structure
docs.text:
test_pypi_pru/
├── main.py           # Main function
├── sub1/
│   └── modulo1.py   # Numerical functions
└── sub2/
    └── modulo2.py   # DataFrame utilities

docs.title: Detailed Examples
docs.text: This page contains advanced usage examples of the test_pypi_pru package.

docs.title: Statistical Analysis with NumPy
docs.text:
import numpy as np
from test_pypi_pru import func1, func2

# Generate sample data
np.random.seed(42)
data = np.random.randn(1000)

# Calculate basic statistics
mean = data.mean()
std = data.std()

print(f"Mean: {mean:.4f}")
print(f"Standard deviation: {std:.4f}")

# Normalize and square
normalized = (data - mean) / std
squared = func1(normalized)

print(f"Mean of normalized squares: {squared.mean():.4f}")

docs.title: Batch Processing
docs.text:
import numpy as np
from test_pypi_pru import func1

# Process data in batches to optimize memory
def process_large_dataset(total_size, batch_size=10000):
    results = []

    for i in range(0, total_size, batch_size):
        # Generate batch
        batch = np.arange(i, min(i + batch_size, total_size))

        # Process with func1
        processed = func1(batch)

        # Accumulate results
        results.append(processed.sum())

    return np.array(results)

# Process 1 million numbers in batches of 10k
batch_results = process_large_dataset(1_000_000)
print(f"Total: {batch_results.sum()}")

docs.title: Complete Data Pipeline
docs.text:
import pandas as pd
from test_pypi_pru import get_dataframe, get_average_age

# Get base data
df = get_dataframe()

# Add calculated column
df['Age_Squared'] = df['Age'] ** 2

# Filter and sort
young_people = df[df['Age'] < 32].sort_values('Age')
print(young_people)

# Calculate average of subset
avg = get_average_age(young_people)
print(f"Average age of people < 32: {avg}")

docs.title: Working with Custom Data
docs.text:
import pandas as pd
from test_pypi_pru import get_average_age

# Create custom dataset
employees = pd.DataFrame({
    'Name': ['Ana', 'Juan', 'María', 'Pedro', 'Lucía'],
    'Age': [28, 35, 42, 31, 29],
    'Department': ['IT', 'HR', 'IT', 'Sales', 'IT'],
    'Salary': [50000, 45000, 60000, 48000, 52000]
})

# Analysis by department
for dept in employees['Department'].unique():
    dept_data = employees[employees['Department'] == dept]
    avg_age = get_average_age(dept_data)
    avg_salary = dept_data['Salary'].mean()

    print(f"{dept}:")
    print(f"  Average age: {avg_age:.1f}")
    print(f"  Average salary: ${avg_salary:,.0f}")

docs.title: Complete Analysis Pipeline
docs.text:
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
from test_pypi_pru import func1, func2, get_dataframe, get_average_age

# 1. Get data
df = get_dataframe()

# 2. Calculate average age
avg_age = get_average_age(df)
print(f"Average age: {avg_age}")

# 3. Normalize ages using NumPy
ages_array = df['Age'].values
normalized_ages = (ages_array - avg_age) / ages_array.std()

# 4. Calculate squared deviations
squared_deviations = func1(normalized_ages)

# 5. Add results to DataFrame
df['Normalized_Age'] = normalized_ages
df['Squared_Deviation'] = squared_deviations

# 6. Round values for presentation
df['Squared_Deviation_Rounded'] = df['Squared_Deviation'].apply(
    lambda x: func2(x, decimals=3)
)

print(df)

docs.title: Data Validation
docs.text:
import numpy as np
from test_pypi_pru import func1, func2

def validate_and_process(data, max_value=100):
    """
    Validate and process a data array.
    """
    # Validate type
    if not isinstance(data, np.ndarray):
        data = np.array(data)

    # Validate range
    if (data > max_value).any():
        raise ValueError(f"Data exceeds maximum allowed: {max_value}")

    # Process: square
    processed = func1(data)

    # Normalize result
    max_processed = processed.max()
    normalized = processed / max_processed

    # Round each element
    rounded = np.array([
        func2(val, decimals=4) for val in normalized
    ])

    return rounded

# Usage
test_data = np.array([10, 20, 30, 40, 50])
result = validate_and_process(test_data)
print(result)

docs.title: Performance Comparison
docs.text:
import time
import numpy as np
from test_pypi_pru import func1

# Compare performance: Cython vs pure Python
sizes = [1000, 10000, 100000, 1000000]

for size in sizes:
    data = np.arange(size, dtype=float)

    # With compiled function (Cython)
    start = time.time()
    result_cython = func1(data)
    time_cython = time.time() - start

    # Pure Python
    start = time.time()
    result_python = np.square(data)
    time_python = time.time() - start

    speedup = time_python / time_cython
    print(f"Size: {size:>7} | "
          f"Cython: {time_cython:.6f}s | "
          f"Python: {time_python:.6f}s | "
          f"Speedup: {speedup:.2f}x")

docs.title: Scoring System
docs.text:
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
from test_pypi_pru import func1, get_average_age

# Student data
students = pd.DataFrame({
    'Name': ['Ana', 'Bob', 'Carlos', 'Diana'],
    'Age': [20, 22, 21, 23],
    'Score': [85, 90, 78, 92]
})

# Normalize scores by age
avg_age = get_average_age(students)
age_factor = students['Age'] / avg_age

# Apply quadratic penalty
penalty = func1(age_factor - 1)  # Penalize deviation from average age

# Calculate adjusted score
students['Adjusted_Score'] = students['Score'] * (1 - 0.1 * penalty)

print(students[['Name', 'Score', 'Adjusted_Score']])

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text: This guide will help you get started using test_pypi_pru in your Python projects.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
First, install the package from Test PyPI:

pip install -i https://test.pypi.org/simple/ test-pypi-pru

docs.title: Import the Package
docs.text:
You can import individual functions or the entire package:

# Import specific functions
from test_pypi_pru import func1, func2, func3
from test_pypi_pru import get_dataframe, get_average_age
from test_pypi_pru import my_function

# Or import the entire package
import test_pypi_pru as tpp

docs.title: 1. Numerical Operations with NumPy
docs.text:
The sub1 module provides optimized functions for NumPy arrays:

import numpy as np
from test_pypi_pru import func1, func2, func3

# func1: Square elements of an array
data = np.array([1, 2, 3, 4, 5])
squared = func1(data)
print(squared)
# Output: [ 1  4  9 16 25]

# func2: Square and round
value = 3.14159
rounded = func2(value, decimals=2)
print(rounded)
# Output: 9.87

# func3: Compute quadratic (value + 1)^2
result = func3(2.5)
print(result)
# Output: 12.25
reversed_text = func3(text) print(reversed_text)

docs.title: Output: 'nohtyP'
docs.text:
### 2. Working with Pandas DataFrames

The `sub2` module provides utilities for working with DataFrames:

```python
from test_pypi_pru import get_dataframe, get_average_age

# Get a sample DataFrame
df = get_dataframe()
print(df)
# Output:
#     Name  Age      City
# 0  Alice   25  New York
# 1    Bob   30    London
# 2  Charlie 35     Paris

# Calculate average age
avg_age = get_average_age(df)
print(f"Average age: {avg_age}")
# Output: Average age: 30.0

docs.title: 3. Main Function
docs.text:
The main function of the package:

from test_pypi_pru import my_function

# Multiply two numbers
result = my_function(5, 3)
print(result)
# Output: 15

# Note: Despite the "sum" name in the docstring,
# this function performs multiplication using np.prod

docs.title: Working with Large Arrays
docs.text:
import numpy as np
from test_pypi_pru import func1

# Process a large array
large_array = np.arange(1_000_000)
squared = func1(large_array)

print(f"Sum of squares: {squared.sum()}")
# Operations are optimized with Cython for better performance

docs.title: Data Processing with Pandas
docs.text:
import pandas as pd
from test_pypi_pru import get_average_age

# Use with your own data
my_data = pd.DataFrame({
    'Name': ['David', 'Emma', 'Frank'],
    'Age': [28, 32, 45],
    'City': ['Berlin', 'Madrid', 'Rome']
})

average = get_average_age(my_data)
print(f"Average age in my dataset: {average}")

docs.title: Verify Installation
docs.text:
To verify that the package is correctly installed:

import test_pypi_pru
print(test_pypi_pru.__version__)
# Output: 0.6.17

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Explore the Complete API Reference to see all available functions
  • Review the Detailed Examples with more complex use cases
  • Check the source code on GitHub

docs.title: Import Error
docs.text:
If you encounter import errors:

# ❌ Incorrect
from test_pypi_pru import func4  # Does not exist

# ✅ Correct
from test_pypi_pru import get_dataframe

See the API Reference for available functions.

docs.title: Performance Issues
docs.text:
If you experience performance issues with large arrays:

  1. Make sure you're using NumPy >= 2.4.2
  2. Verify the package was installed correctly (must be compiled)
  3. Consider using contiguous arrays in memory with np.ascontiguousarray()

docs.title: test_pypi_pru.main
docs.text:
Main utilities for the package.

The functions here are small examples used in the project. Docstrings follow the NumPy style and include LaTeX where appropriate.

docs.title: my_function
docs.text:
my_function(x: int, y: int) -> int

Return the product of two integers.

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default x int

First integer.

required y int

Second integer.

required

Returns:

Type Description int

The product :math:x imes y computed using NumPy.

Examples:

>>> my_function(2, 3)
6
Source code in src/test_pypi_pru/main.py 
def my_function(x: int, y: int) -> int:
    """Return the product of two integers.

    Parameters
    ----------
    x : int
        First integer.
    y : int
        Second integer.

    Returns
    -------
    int
        The product :math:`x \times y` computed using NumPy.

    Examples
    --------
    >>> my_function(2, 3)
    6
    """

    return int(np.prod([x, y]))

docs.title: Submodule 1: Numerical Functions
docs.text: This module contains optimized functions for numerical operations with NumPy.

docs.title: test_pypi_pru.sub1.modulo1
docs.text:
Utilities in the sub1.modulo1 module.

This module provides small helper functions used by the package. Docstrings follow the NumPy style and include LaTeX where sensible.

Examples:

>>> import numpy as np
>>> from test_pypi_pru.sub1.modulo1 import func1
>>> func1(np.array([1, 2, 3]))
array([1, 4, 9])

docs.title: func1
docs.text:
func1(data: ndarray) -> ndarray

Element-wise square of an array.

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default data ndarray

Input array of numeric values.

required

Returns:

Type Description ndarray

Array where each element is the square of the corresponding input element. Computed element-wise as \(f(x) = x^{2}\).

Examples:

>>> import numpy as np
>>> func1(np.array([1, 2]))
array([1, 4])
Source code in src/test_pypi_pru/sub1/modulo1.py 
def func1(data: np.ndarray) -> np.ndarray:
    """Element-wise square of an array.

    Parameters
    ----------
    data : numpy.ndarray
        Input array of numeric values.

    Returns
    -------
    numpy.ndarray
        Array where each element is the square of the corresponding input
        element. Computed element-wise as $f(x) = x^{2}$.

    Examples
    --------
    >>> import numpy as np
    >>> func1(np.array([1, 2]))
    array([1, 4])
    """
    return np.square(data)

docs.title: func2
docs.text:
func2(value: float, decimals: int) -> float

Square a value and round to a number of decimal places.

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default value float

Input numeric value to be squared.

required decimals int

Number of decimal places to round the squared result to.

required

Returns:

Type Description float

The result of rounding \(value^{2}\) to decimals decimal places, i.e. \(\mathrm{round}(value^{2}, decimals)\).

Examples:

>>> func2(1.2345, 2)
1.52
Source code in src/test_pypi_pru/sub1/modulo1.py 
def func2(value: float, decimals: int) -> float:
    """Square a value and round to a number of decimal places.

    Parameters
    ----------
    value : float
        Input numeric value to be squared.
    decimals : int
        Number of decimal places to round the squared result to.

    Returns
    -------
    float
        The result of rounding $value^{2}$ to ``decimals`` decimal places,
        i.e. $\\mathrm{round}(value^{2}, decimals)$.

    Examples
    --------
    >>> func2(1.2345, 2)
    1.52
    """
    value = value**2
    return round(value, decimals)

docs.title: func3
docs.text:
func3(value: float) -> float

Compute the quadratic (value + 1)^2 using its expanded form.

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default value float

Input numeric value.

required

Returns:

Type Description float

The computed value of \((value + 1)^{2}\), i.e. \(value^{2} + 2\,value + 1\).

Notes

The expanded form is used for clarity; numerically it is equivalent to computing (value + 1)**2.

Examples:

>>> func3(2.0)
9.0
>>> func3(0.5)
2.25
Source code in src/test_pypi_pru/sub1/modulo1.py 
def func3(value: float) -> float:
    """Compute the quadratic (value + 1)^2 using its expanded form.

    Parameters
    ----------
    value : float
        Input numeric value.

    Returns
    -------
    float
        The computed value of $(value + 1)^{2}$, i.e. $value^{2} + 2\\,value + 1$.

    Notes
    -----
    The expanded form is used for clarity; numerically it is equivalent to
    computing ``(value + 1)**2``.

    Examples
    --------
    >>> func3(2.0)
    9.0
    >>> func3(0.5)
    2.25
    """
    return value**2 + 2 * value + 1

docs.title: Submodule 2: DataFrame Utilities
docs.text: This module provides functions for working with Pandas DataFrames.

docs.title: test_pypi_pru.sub2.modulo2
docs.text:
Helpers for the sub2 package.

This module provides small utilities that return a sample :class:pandas.DataFrame and compute simple statistics. Docstrings follow the NumPy style and include LaTeX where appropriate.

docs.title: get_dataframe
docs.text:
get_dataframe() -> DataFrame

Return a sample DataFrame.

Returns:

Type Description DataFrame

DataFrame with columns Name, Age and City constructed from an internal sample dictionary.

Examples:

>>> df = get_dataframe()
>>> list(df.columns)
['Name', 'Age', 'City']
Source code in src/test_pypi_pru/sub2/modulo2.py 
def get_dataframe() -> pd.DataFrame:
    """Return a sample DataFrame.

    Returns
    -------
    pandas.DataFrame
        DataFrame with columns ``Name``, ``Age`` and ``City`` constructed from
        an internal sample dictionary.

    Examples
    --------
    >>> df = get_dataframe()
    >>> list(df.columns)
    ['Name', 'Age', 'City']
    """
    return pd.DataFrame(data)

docs.title: get_average_age
docs.text:
get_average_age(dataframe: DataFrame) -> float

Compute the average age from a DataFrame.

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default dataframe DataFrame

DataFrame containing an Age column with numeric values.

required

Returns:

Type Description float

Mean of the Age column, computed as \(\bar{a} = \frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=1}^{N} a_i\).

Examples:

>>> df = get_dataframe()
>>> get_average_age(df)
30.0
Source code in src/test_pypi_pru/sub2/modulo2.py 
def get_average_age(dataframe: pd.DataFrame) -> float:
    """Compute the average age from a DataFrame.

    Parameters
    ----------
    dataframe : pandas.DataFrame
        DataFrame containing an ``Age`` column with numeric values.

    Returns
    -------
    float
        Mean of the ``Age`` column, computed as
        $\\bar{a} = \\frac{1}{N} \\sum_{i=1}^{N} a_i$.

    Examples
    --------
    >>> df = get_dataframe()
    >>> get_average_age(df)
    30.0
    """
    return dataframe["Age"].mean()
